sen.j: うつそみの人にあるわれや明日よりは 二上山を弟背とわが見む
sen.e: Now you are dead, and still I live; from tomorrow I will see Mt. Futakami as my brother.

sen.j: 磯の上に生ふる馬酔木を手折らめど 見すべき君がありといわなくに
sen.e: Even though I tries to break off the flowering ashibi branch on the rock, nobody tells me that you are still here to be shown the branch by me.

sen.j: ももづたふ磐余の池に鳴く鴨を今日のみ見てや雲隠りなむ
sen.e: It would be the last day for me to see a wild duck on the pond of Iware; Would I die today?

sen.j: 金烏臨西舎 （金烏 西舎に臨み）
sen.e: The golden sun has already declined in the west.

sen.j: 鼓声催短命 （鼓声 短命を催す）
sen.e: A drum sounds like urging my short life to end.

sen.j: 泉路無賓主 （泉路 賓主無し）
sen.e: On my last journey to the land of the dead, there is no difference between a host and a guest.

sen.j: 此夕誰家向 （この夕 誰が家にか向ふ）
sen.e: This evening I have to leave my house, heading for the land of the dead.

sen.e: His grave is near the top of Odake, Mt. nijo (Nara and Osaka Prefectures), which is located between Osaka and Nara Prefectures. (the Imperial Household Agency put the gravestone with the words, 'The grave of Imperial Prince Otsu at Mt. Nijo')
